Award.AwardTitle: The Influence of Efficacy, Framing, and Political Orientation on Selective Perception and Selective Exposure: The Case of Atmospheric Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
A persistent problem for science communicators is how best to discuss controversial science issues. Communication is made especially difficult due to biases that arise through selective exposure and selective perception - individuals tend to selectively view and interpret messages in ways that reinforce previously held values and beliefs. The result is that attempts to communicate about science issues often amplify political polarization, and fail to spur action to mitigate or adapt to the relevant risks. The case of atmospheric change has been particularly rife with communication problems. This research draws primarily from the extended parallel process model (EPPM), which emphasizes the role of efficacy in effective risk communication, and the literature on framing processes to investigate how the media has discussed controversal science issues and what kinds of narratives may be effective in overcoming selective perception and selective exposure. Through a media content analysis and a series of experiments the project: 1) identifies how print, television, and online news media have thematically framed the controversal science issues and discussed the efficacy of efforts to address the issue, 2) investigates how the EPPM may be applied to politically charged issues, with a focus on how political orientation may moderate the impacts of changes in descriptions of efficacy on individuals' perceptions of the issue, and 3) explores how changes in media climate change frames and descriptions of efficacy, respectively, may cause individuals with varying political orientations to pay selective attention to media stories.

Using atmospheric change as a case study, this project will expand our understanding of how the news media represent controversal science issues and test strategies for overcoming individual biases in the selection and processing of science messages. It will advance risk communication theory by increasing our knowledge of how to use the EPPM and framing theory to develop messages that resonate across broad audiences and, in so doing, will make novel connections across multiple disciplines. In addition to its theoretical contributions, this research will provide new methods that practitioners may use to create scientifically informed messages that more effectively communicate controversal science issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The Influence of Efficacy, Framing, and Political Orientation on Selective Perception and Selective Exposure: The Case of Atmospheric Change

This research program examined how climate change is discussed in the public sphere and how individuals attend to and interpret information about climate change. The first part of the project involved a content analysis of how television and print news outlets cover the issue of climate change. The content analysis was followed by a series of experiments examining how variations in news stories about climate change may affect public engagement on the issue. In particular, we were interested in the extent to which news stories included information about the efficacy, or likely effectiveness, of actions to address climate change, and the influence of this information on audiences.

In content analyses of news stories about climate change in U.S. network television news and in major U.S. newspapers, we found that while the U.S. news media paints a relatively clear picture of the threat posed by climate change to the American public – particularly in terms of its environmental impacts, it sends a mixed message about the likely efficacy of taking action to address climate change. News stories that discussed actions that can be taken to address climate change often paired information about the benefits of such action with information about obstacles to or downsides of taking action. Actions also were discussed primarily in terms of political conflict. We also found that the impacts of climate change and actions that can be taken to address climate change were discussed with similar frequencies, but rarely together in the same news story. The analysis of U.S. newspapers also revealed differences in non-editorial news coverage between major newspapers (The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, and USA Today). The Wall Street Journal was the least likely to discuss impacts of climate change, and when discussing actions, was most likely to discuss obstacles to action, political conflict, and potential negative economic consequences.

A series of experiments was conducted to test the effects of news stories that included textual and/or visual information about actions to address climate change and the efficacy of those actions. Overall, the results indicate that climate change news stories that include information about actions and efficacy, relative to stories that only discuss the impacts of climate change, can help increase feelings of hope and the perception that one can do something about climate change. These perceptions, in turn, increase individuals’ intentions to engage in political activities in support of climate action and to adopt energy conservation behaviors. In most cases, these effects occurred regardless of individuals’ political orientation.  

A core part of the funded research was to empirically test a new conceptualization of political efficacy in the context of climate change that included internal efficacy, external efficacy, and response efficacy. Perceived internal efficacy refers to the belief that an individual can engage in an action, such as write a letter to Congress. Perceived external efficacy refers to the belief that key decision makers, such as members of Congress, will respond to public calls for action. Perceived response efficacy refers to the belief that actions taken by decision makers will actually be effective in addressing the issue. We found that all three of these types of perceived efficacy play a distinct, significant role in determining how politically engaged an individual is on the issue of climate change. Experimental tests of news messages containing different types of efficacy information yielded mixed results; although a message containing positive internal efficacy information increased perceived internal efficacy and a message containing negative external efficacy information decreased perceived external efficacy, no other type of positive or negative efficacy information influenced the respective type of perceived efficacy.

A final set of experiments examined how variations in the headlines of online news stories about climate change influence the likelihood that individuals will click on and read these stories. Preliminary results indicate a preference for news stories that relate climate change to health.

The results of this research can help improve the role communication can play in counteracting the adverse impacts of climate change. For strategic communicators, our results point to more effective methods for communicating the risks of climate change and ways to mitigate or adapt to the relevant risks. In particular, our results suggest that including information about actions and the political efficacy of those actions may be a productive way to broaden public engagement with climate change. For journalists, our results are a reminder that their reporting and editorial decisions have consequences for public opinion and engagement with climate change.
